Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Phononic Surfaces for Flow Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Interdisciplinary Research project presents a new concept for surfaces interacting with fluids - flexible surfaces that can be designed to hydroelastically or aeroelastically interact with boundary-layer flow in a favorable manner leading to reduction of drag forces. The basic idea, which is inspired by condensed matter physics, is to have a periodic lattice structure at the inner core of the surface, hence the phrase phononic surface. The surface will be primarily designed to delay laminar-to-turbulence transition and separation, and also to cause drag reduction for fully developed turbulent flow. Other functions that can be simultaneously realized are reduction of overall vibrations and structural noise emission. The research plan involves investigation of an efficient, systematic and integrated methodology for modeling, analysis and design of the proposed phononic surfaces. For the periodic lattice unit cell band structure calculation, a novel and efficient computational scheme based on modal analysis will be utilized. Specialized genetic algorithm operators will be created for the unit cell optimization. Direct numerical simulation of the flow and the elastic wave motion in the surface will be carried out. The unit-cell design will be performed independently of the full coupled solid-fluid simulations thus providing crucial computational savings.

The interdisciplinary nature of the research, at the cross-roads of dynamical systems, condensed matter physics and fluid dynamics will enrich the various aspects of the planned research. Elucidating the nature of the interaction between the dispersive periodic waves in and beneath the solid surface and the nonlinear and unstable fluid waves will constitute a new discovery involving fundamental physical phenomena. The subsequent utilization of this knowledge promises to open a new direction in flow control. For streamlined ships and aircrafts, or vehicles in general, the proposed drag-reduction concept will bring about substantial improvements in fuel efficiency and hence economic and environmental benefits. Gains to the performance of turbines of different sorts could also be realized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interaction between a viscous fluid and a solid surface in relative motion represents a dynamical process that lies at the heart of the generation of skin-friction drag for air, sea and land vehicles, as well as in long-range pipelines that transport fluids. The intensity of the skin-friciton drag is a prime factor that determines fuel efficiency-the higher the drag the lower the fuel efficiency. A flow control technique that significantly reduces drag, and that can be practically implemented, promises to have a profound impact on reducing the dependence of the world's population on fossil fuels for global transport. Because skin friction drag is lower in laminar than in turbulent flows, drag reduction can potentially be achieved by delaying laminar-to-turbulent transition, which, in principle may be accomplished by tuning a surface's spatiotemporal elastic deformation profile in a manner that leads to countering the core mechanisms influencing transition, such as flow instabilities. The ability to precisely manipulate fluid-structure interactions at the interface also provides further possibilities for flow control, e.g., lift enhancement, improved vehicle maneuverability and separation delay, in addition to applications that benefit from increasing turbulence intensity such as fluid mixing and combustion.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, the nature of phased wave motion in a flow and its intricate interaction with an elastic solid has been unraveled and utilized toward the establishment of a precise and robust passive technique for flow control. This technique was demonstrated by stimulating a fully developed plane Poiseuille (channel) flow whereby a small portion of an otherwise rigid wall is replaced with a one-dimensional phononic crystal (see Fig. 1). A Tollmien-Schlichting (TS) wave was introduced to the flow as an evolving disturbance. Upon tuning the frequency-dependent phase and amplitude relations of the surface of the phononic crystal that interfaces with the flow, the TS wave was shown to stabilize, or destabilize, as needed (see Fig. 2). A theory of subsurface phonons has been developed that provides an accurate prediction of this behavior without the need for a flow simulation (see Fig. 3). This new concept, which is inspired by principles from condensed matter physics, represents an unprecedented capability to passively synchronize wave propagation across a fluid-structure interface and achieve favorable, and predictable, alterations to the floiw properties. [Ref.: Hussein et al., Proc. R. Soc. A 471, 20140928, 2015]

Broader Impact: The successful outcome of this research has laid the foundation for a new paradigm for solid-fluid interaction and stability control in transitional flow, which promises to introduce strong reductions in drag in aircrafts, marine vessels, land vehicles, wind turbines, gas and oil pipelines, among other industrial applications. The potential economic and environmental benefits due to savings from applying the drag reduction mechanism introduced in this research are vast. In addition, the rich multi-disciplinary nature of the underlying flow control problem, and the associated visually appealing wave and fluid phenomena, have attracted strong involvement from both graduate and undergraduate students. The work has been disseminated through several journal publicaitons as well as presentations in national and international conferences.
